arm_group.description: preoperative none substitution of i.v. fluids.
preoperative substitution of a defined amount of i.v. fluids (8 ml/kg RingerAcetate solution for 15 min prior to introduction of anesthesia).

brief_summary.textblock:
Preoperative fasting can evoke a hypovolemia which may cause a hemodynamic instability
      during introduction of anesthesia.

      The purpose of this study is to test the hypothesis that a defined preoperative volume
      substitution compared to standard procedure will result in a reduced incidence of
      hemodynamic instabilities during introduction of anesthesia in elective surgery patients.

clinical_study.brief_title: Preoperative Volume Substitution in Elective Surgery Patients

detailed_description.textblock:
The preoperative fasting period often lasts longer than 2 hours as recommended by various
      national and international anesthetic guidelines. Thus, hypovolemia is more often then
      anticipated. In awake patients this condition is often masked. Introduction of anesthesia
      often leads to an unmasking of hypovolemia with a consecutive hemodynamic instability.

      Aim of the study is to test the hypothesis that a preoperative volume substitution (8 ml/kg
      RingerAcetate Solution in 15 min. prior to introduction of anesthesia) reduces possible
      hemodynamic instabilities during initiation of anesthesia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Age  ≥ 18 years

          -  thyreoid, parathyroid or gallbladder surgery

          -  general anesthesia

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  coronary artery disease

          -  congestive heart disease (≥ New York Heart Association (NYHA) 2)

          -  insulin dependent diabetes mellitus

          -  renal insufficiency (creatinine > 2,0 mg/dl)

          -  cerebrovascular disease

          -  severe hypertension (≥ antihypertensive drugs)

facility.name: University Hospital of Marburg, Department of Anesthesia

clinical_study.official_title: Preoperative Volume Substitution in Fasting Patients Undergoing Elective Surgery - Impact on Hemodynamic Stability During Anesthesia

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Anesthesia and Intensive Care Medicine, University Hospital Marburg, Germany

primary_outcome.description:
Hemodynamic instability during induction of anesthesia (0-10 min), defined as at least one of the following:
Systolic blood pressure < 80 mmHg or decrease of 20% in preexistent  hypertension
Mean blood pressure < 50 mmHg or decrease of 20% or > 20 mmHg in preexistent hypertension
Bradycardia < 45/min or decrease of 20% in preexistent bradycardia < 60/min.
Tachycardia > 120/min
Cardiac index < 2.0 l/min/m²
primary_outcome.time_frame: at time of introduction of anesthesia

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: transthoracic echocardiographic parasternal short axis enddiastolic area
transthoracic echocardiographic inferior vena cava diameter

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Treatment
